Yttrium oxide (Y2O3), Copper Nitrate (Cu(NO3)2, and Barium Nitrate (Ba(NO3)2 Finally, Citric acid

You might need to purify Yttrium oxide (Y2O3) to Yttrium Nitrate (Y(NO3)3, So to do that you need to mix 200 Ml of water (3 H2O) with some concentrated nitric acid (6 HNO3). Then after it’s done mixing add the Yttrium oxide, Then filter through some cotton and sea light.

Once that’s done, make sure to get rid of most of the water. Now, wait for it to cool to room temperature. If this doesn’t work, force it to crystallize using a rod. Once you waited for a day make sure to break it down.

NileRed, I have a challenge for you to undertake.

Previously, humanity made a superconductor La(2-x)Ba(x)CuO4 with the maximum Tc at ~30 K. YBa2Cu3O7 is the next superconductor above the previous one with a Tc at ~92 K. Do you know the atomic difference between these supermagnets? The answer is exactly one element which directly shares a vertical adjacency with each other. Therefore, I have one request. Scandium is the element directly above Yttrium and Lanthanum which I predict would have a Tc of ~140 K +/- an unknown margin of error. If you will make the same material as before, but with Scandium instead of Yttrium or Lanthanum, aka. Sc(w)Ba(x)Cu(y)O(z) or SBCO, then I will be happy as a viewer.

Correct me if I am wrong but I think this flux pinning phenomenon happens because of Faraday's law of induction. Since the magnet is fixed in place due to the magnetic field created by the induced current in the superconductor, any change in magnetic flux is canceled by this generated field so the magnet should be fixed in space and cannot move in any direction to preserve the law of induction.

As a solid state chemist, there were a few things here that I felt could have been done better.

When dealing with fine powders like these, pouring them like you did into a single container is not a great idea. Obviously you wet doing so in a hood and were being safe but, it would be a good idea to mention that type of safety info.

Also, when it came to grinding up the pellets you made in order to further oxidize them, this was not necessary at all. It may not make a lot of sense to people unfamiliar with solid state physics but, atoms in solids are not at all static. The solids will move through a process called diffusion. Increases in temperature and increases in proximity lead to an increase in diffusion rate. This means that when your solids are packed tightly together in a pellet, even though it might take a bit more time for the oxygen to seep into them because of the reduced surface area with the oxygen, it means that if you give it enough time, your product will be incredibly uniform. I would even say you would be better off doing this in a single step where you press the original oxide mixture into a pellet and heat it for a few days. Likely, your lack of oxygen in the initial steps is probably just due to not all of the oxides reacting together due to a lack of diffusion through the fluffy powder. So, the individual oxides were not picking up the extra oxygen.

You do obviously have to increase the dwell time the thicker your pellets. So, often a larger diameter, thinner pellet can be better.

It's not just regions with impurities that get flux pinning through them. A strong enough magnetic field destroys the superconductivity much like too high a temperature, so in particular if you cool it while it's in contact with the magnet some of the flux will be pinned in vortices whose centers are regions of nonsuperconducting stuff. This only happens in Type II superconductors though, in type I superconductors the regular and superconducting states are separate by a phase transition with no "mixed" regions in between. Type II superconductors like cuprates want to maximize the surface area of the regular and superconducting states so the formation of such flux vortices is energetically favored.

The length of time in the furnace was probably the most critical factor. Another one would be they needed to be heated after compression. When I did this experiment in the second year of my physics degree, we didn't even use an oxygenated oven (or did any of the dissolving and mixing as we just mixed the powders). Apparently, the oxygen in the oxides and the surrounding air is enough to make a superconductor when in the pellet form. In the experiment, we compressed 2-3 g of YBCO to 4000 psi, then heated it at 900c for 20 hours. It was already superconducting at this point but we crushed it and recompressed it again then heated it to 950c for another 20 hours. YBCO needed to be heated after compression so that the lattices can align in the same direction, and grinding/ making/heating the pellet again can make larger crystallites.

Close, but you missed something important:
the magnetic field of the magnet induces a CURRENT in the super conductor.
This induced current generates a repelling magnetic field.
super conductors conduct so well that the current flow is strong enough to produce a magnetic field that is basically equal to that of the one that produced it, but in a different direction.
ALL CONDUCTORS DO THIS. Super Conductors just do it better than all the others.

Fun fact about YBCO superconductors: the team who lead to these cuprate blades HTS (high temp superconductors), Muller & Bednorz thought that the Jahn-Teller effect might be the cause behind the superconductivity of these ceramic materials, as the lattice of the material would allow Copper pairs to pass through freely in an "organized' fashion, however, now we think this might not be the case. (also, a little note to add is that in superconductor physics, the temp unit we always use is K, and for any super conductor with a Tc above 77K or the temp of liquid nitrogen, we call them HTSs).

That's a neat little furnace. Some of the Chinese stuff is actually catching up in quality. A few years ago you would have gotten absolute junk; maybe a toaster oven dressed up to look like a furnace.

Recently I was in the market for a ballistic helmet. You could go with a Chinese ACH-style IIIA for $150 off wish or ali baba or whatever, or an American one for $450 - $1200. I went for a $500 American one 'cause I thought the Chinese ones would be some ABS plastic airsoft helmet that couldn't stop a BB gun. But I did more research after that and viewed some test videos, and those cheapo Chinese helmets are resisting .44 magnum shots at 10 feet - just as good as my $500 one. they're actually the real deal.

So between your furnace and the helmets, it's actually looking like it's becoming safer to trust some of the claims of Chinese sellers.

You really need to use a stir bar on those pyrolysis reactions. You end up with a better product due to superior mixing, and the reaction proceeds much more evenly throughout the container. Sometimes the bar will stop spinning right before the reaction goes off, but it has still done its job. I recommend high temp stir bars, but honestly the teflon ones survive well enough.

Source: I used to do these reactions for making an electrode material for fuel cells. Except ours were... much more violent.... explosive even. (Hence why we clamped a bunch of wire gauze on top of the beaker.)

EDIT: You also need a binder material when pressing pellets. It would help make them "perfect" and it just burns off during sintering so it doesn't affect your final product. Of course, if you can make them without it's better, but it certainly makes making them easier.

EDIT2: Also, you REALLY want to mill the material before pressing pellets. You want the smallest particles you can get and you want them to all be consistent. We would let ours sit in a ball mill for 8-12 hours. You can make one yourself by just getting yourself some ceramic balls (ours were ysz... I think) and just putting them in a flat sided container with your powder, then rolling that container between two cylinders, using a motor to turn one of the cylinders. We had an expensive mill that used special containers, but you can do it pretty well the way I described.

This has probably been said 500 times in the sea of 12k comments below but I still feel like mentioning it. Infact you probably have thought of it. In that last step, sintering, I think that it the powder does have a good bit of YBCO6 and then the oxygen isn't getting inside of the pellet. This would cause the diamagnetic force to be only from the outside material instead of the entire thing, which would explain why the 1.9 mm worked better at first. With it being thicker, it would make sense that it just required a lot more time. Your pellets weren't growing in diameter, just in height, meaning that there was little change in surface compared to mass. I think if for some ungodly reason you decided to make a 1 kilogram pillar with the same diameter, it simply wouldnt sinter correctly. (also it would have to go in the tube sideways, if it even fit.)

Nile, an interesting fact about superconductors and magnets is that it doesn't just perfectly repel magnets, it will perfectly attract them as well; you can take the superconductor with the magnet floating on top and turn it upside down, and the magnet should float underneath it at the same distance from the superconductor. The Royal Institutes has a fantastic video demonstrating a Mobius strip neodymium magnet track with a little superconductor car that zooms around, levitating and hanging underneath as it twists and turns in 3d space.

The amazing part to me is more that a ceramic substance, which are normally EXTREMELY good insulators conducts electricity. Ceramics were used as some of the first insulators in knob and tube wiring, for instance. It doesn't make good TV, but it'd still be sort of cool to see a ceramic substance conduct electricity by putting an ohm-meter on it. You'd likely need something fairly specialized to measure micro-ohms though.

You could also make a loop of superconductor, induce a current in it, remove the voltage, and you've created an electro-magnet with no applied power that should last as long as your cooling does.

One thing I'm curious about is, how does something crushed so tightly still allow oxygen to penetrate, and react? I'd expect that something like this, especially after being fired a first time, would be impermeable to oxygen. Maybe there's something going on at these high temperatures I don't understand, or maybe the ceramic is more porous than I'd expect?

It are not the defects that allow magetic field to go through. It is because its a type-II superconductor. Which means that the meisner current can not become strong enough to cancel out the magnetic field inside the conductor. Instead the conductor allows "vortexes" to through the material. These vortexes allow quantized magnetic fields to go through the material. And these vortexes prefer to move to those defects. So far my understanding during my lectures :)

I actually made the same compound in my inorganics lab. We compared two recipes:We both used laboratory grade Y2O3 and CuO. One Group then used BaCO3 and the other used Ba(O2)2 (Bariumperoxide). We both just put the powdered precursers in a Mortar and mixed it in there. Then we put it in the same kind of oven you used at 900°C, crushed and mixed it again in the mortar and made a pellet with the same kind of press you used. From there the methods deviated. The Corbonate-Group just put it in the oven under air, the Peroxide-Group put it in the oven under pure Oxygen flow and for a longer time. Both turned out working (we tested it by floating it over a magnet we salvaged from a hard drive), but the carbonate one worked better. Our instructor was also disappointed, that the one with less steps worked better than the one with more.
When we looked at the surface of both pellets under a scanning electron microscope we could see that the grains in the peroxide one (with the longer oven time) was more strongly sintered together.
That was weird because that one worked worse. But oh whatever, sometimes Chemistry is just weird. ^^

By the way, you can make an inexpensive tube furnace by getting a quartz tube, wrapping it in a layer of high temperature fabric, wrapping the correct amount resistance wire around it for your type of power, wrap the whole thing in insulation and then put it in a metal housing. Then insert a thermocouple and control the temperature with a standard temperature controller. This costs a lot less than a purchased tube furnace, but of course the tube furnace looks cooler.

You might have already done so, but you didn't explicitly state it in thy video, so just in case:  that electrolytic capacitor juice that got leaked onto the pcb needs to be cleaned off asap.  You can use some rubbing alcohol and a tooth brush.  Make sure to get any that got under and of the other components as well if you can.  If you use something abrasive, be sure to recoat the board with conformal coating (or even just nail polish) in that area.  The reason is that it will cause the pcb traces to corrode and fail over time if it's not properly treated.

A few tips for pellet pressing:
1: You do need the second anvil (spacer)
2: Make sure you powder is level in the die before pressing.
3: Rotate the die 90 degrees halfway through pressing. You will have to release and then reapply the pressure to do this.

Hi guys, for this video I decided to synthesize the entire universe. Unfortunately, I only found a few books describing how to do this, and they were really vague. So, I just decided to experiment.

In order to perform this reaction, I had to start out with pretty much nothing. This wasn’t really a problem though, and I decided to just expose everything to a lot of light and heat. I then pulled a vacuum on it and I let it sit overnight.

What I had now, was definitely more dense then before, but it was still really fluffy and fragile. I thought I had made a mistake, but it turns out I was just being impatient. I left it there for a billion years, and when I came back, a lot of it fell out of solution, and I was left with a bunch of solid junk. This ended up being way more successful than I expected.

A lot of the solid chunks were heavy metal but most of it was just hydrogen, and it all began to form into these nice spheres. Unfortunately, there were no complex self-preserving organic compounds which was disappointing to say the least.

This didn’t really matter though because I just needed to add some distilled water and solvents and let it sit for another billion years, and life began to form. What I had at this point should have been a complete universe with an Earth and I was pretty excited that I now had intelligent life. When I tested the life, some of it was not as intelligent as I had hoped, but it ended up being fine.

Very cool video, yet two scientific comments: 1) Y(OH)3 is not blue, I recently worked with it and it was a clean white precipitant. It also was colourless in solution. 2) I didn't really get why you repeated the whole cooling and heating routine. It seemed like the problem with reaction was that the ion diffusion in the solid state reaction was just very slow. Letting the reation heat at the highest temperature for another several hours probably could have done the trick as well. The cooling in this sort of reaction is just for the structure to crystallize properly, yet if the reaction was not complete, it also doesn't need to crystallize.

I remember trying to make this stuff back in 1998 while at a science summer camp for high schoolers at the University of Missouri-Rolla (now Missouri Science and Technology). When you got to the point of boiling all the water off and combusting the mixture..I was thinking "Wait for it...."

Ours didn't work either, and watching this video I now know why. We did not do the oxygenation step correctly or for long enough. Additionally, the furnace we used was not a tube furnace and was contaminated with some Iron from other experiments.

We had taken the sample and done XRD to try and figure out why. We found the signature of the iron then. It was disappointing to not float the magnet, but I learned a very valuable lesson that even a failure can be a valid result.

Thank you for this videi. 22 years later, I now know where we went wrong in that experiment. Never stop learning.

And good luck with the magnet.

So I put pomolive dish soap in with it the regular green dish soap. At first it was ok then it start to think out and became real real runny like someone adding water to it, I asked everyone who lived here and they all said they didn't add a thing not even water. So about a week later I saw that they put out more hand soap on the shelves and you can only buy 4 at a time. So I bought 4 went home and put a new one on the bathroom sink to replace the very runny one. I didn't want to throw that away just in case they were sold out and I didn't have any soap to clean our hands so I put it under the sink. This was about the month of May when I put it under the sink. A few days ago I was looking under the bathroom sink for some laundry detergent to put on a shirt that got blood on it from a cut I gotten while chopping up onions, I didn't have any laundry detergent so I saw that watery down hand soap a squirted some out and put cold water on the blood. Cold water is the temp you put on blood stain if you catch it time and not let it set in and it will come out . And there are no small children in this house what so ever if anyone was wondering or worried. Need to why it did that and if it's safe to keep or should I get rid of it?! Btw it did get the stain out but it would have anyways because I caught it in time and didn't let it set in. Cold water on blood is sometimes enough if you don't have soap.

What I like about your videos is you show the problems and mistakes, not just the successes. Too often, we get a sanitized version of reality, particularly on YT.

Also, glad it (finally) worked. When my daughter was young, we tried duplicating several key experiments in physics and in most cases, the original discoverer was lucky to have noticed the effect. Even knowing that it was done and how it was done doesn't guarantee success.

As a youngster, I hated the pre-fabbed science kits (Remco) because while they almost always worked, you really didn't learn/experience anything worthwhile. People learn from their mistakes. Success teaches nothing (often the wrong lesson).

Um, Nile, their numbers are very ok, their ratio of elements (in mg) is 787 : 1 609 : 2 362, which, simplified, makes 1 : 2.043 : 3.001. And perhaps the slight imprecision in barium nitrate is because they adjusted for impurities in their product.

Yttrium(III) oxide's molar weight is 225.81 g, meaning that 0.225 81 g is 1 mmol. And, 1 g divided by 0.225 81 is 4.43 mmol. There are 2 molecules of yttrium, so 8.86 mmol indeed. And yttrium's atomic weight is 88.905 84, so that gives us 787.4 mg of yttrium.

Barium nitrate's molar weight is 261.337 g, meaning that 0.261 337 g is 1 mmol. And, 3.063 g divided by 0.261 337 is 11.72 mmol indeed. But, barium's atomic weight is 137.327, meaning that 11.72 mmol of it is 1 609 mg. Divided by the quantity of yttrium, 787.4, that gives us a ratio of 2.043 which is pretty close to 2.

You got the moles on that one right, so if we take that 1.32 ratio you somehow got to, and divide the amount of barium (1 609 mg) by it, it equals to 1 219. So, it looks like you calculated that ratio from a mixed up yttrium oxide formula where you somehow calculated 3 yttrium atoms (which would weigh 1 182 mg) even though on the previous step you got the moles right.

Copper(II) nitrate trihydrate's molar weight is 241.60 g, meaning that 0.241 60 g is 1 mmol. And, 8.981 g divided by 0.241 60 is 37.17, not 31.2. Given the atomic weight of copper, 63.546, 37.17 mmol give us 2 362 mg of copper. Which, divided by 787.4 mg of yttrium, makes a perfectly good ratio of 2.999 to 3.001 depending on how many decimals you keep during your calculations.

This means you calculated 31.2 * 63.546 = 1 983 mg of copper. Which, divided by 787.4 mg of yttrium, makes a 2.51-ish ratio, not 3.51. Seriously? You replaced a 7 with a 1, and a 3 with a 2 in the same formula? You better up that handwriting game, I think you're getting your numbers mixed up because you didn't take the time to learn how to write un-misreadable numbers.


You were right that they made a mistake about yttrium nitrate hexahydrate, though. But, before you throw their study away claiming you don't trust them, consider the fact that you made three errors and they made one.

Delicious Citric Acid, great for making sour gummy candy. Here's a simple recipe for gummy candy. On a stove top make some gelatin (Jell-O), but instead of only one package use 2 or more to how chewy or tough you want the candy to be. Separate the gelatin into different batches and add flavor and food coloring to taste, optionally add citric acid to make sour gummies. Pour the different gelatin into a mould such as a small ice cube tray. Put the mould into the fridge, now wait. Tada. Now you have candy.

I wanna point out that you must avoid using mortar and pestle made out of steel/iron as any small amount of ferromagnetic impurities can completely destroy the superconductivity in the material. This happens because like a critical temperature the any superconductor has a critical field, which is disrupted by the high magnetisation of ferromagnetic impurities.
In short “Ferromagnets are Superconductivity killers”.

Impurities are not the reason there is flux penetration. Also, the Meisner effect (which is the diamagnetism effect you described first) is only present at very low fields and does not exist at the same time as the vortex state. Above like 100-200 miliTesla (which is the case for your little magnet), the superconductor allows magnetic field through, each containing 1 flux quanta. They exist as a small vortex of supercurrent, leading to a region of non-superconductivity in its centre. This happens because it's energetically favourable. The impurities "just" provide locations where these so-called fluxoids or flux tubes can sit at, to be even lower in energy. Because it takes energy to move such fluxoid, a source of magnetic field (i.e. your magnet) is fixed in space.

It's nice that NordVPN gives you money. But I won't give NordVPN my money. You can set up a rasperry pi at your home for 60 bucks. It can run a vpn server in addition to webserver, mail server, intrusion prevention system, have attached storage, backup server, dns black hole (advertisement filter). All of the software is free and open source. The pi takes a maximum of 5V * 2.5A = 12.5W. so 1h of operation is 0.0125kWh. Suppose 1 kWh costs 30ct, then a month of operation costs you 2.70€ in power. Of course the Pi doesn't run at 2.5A all the time. In addition to NOT sending all of your data to a third party (yes, all your data goes to NordVPN servers and who knows what they do with it), all your data goes to your home. In addition you can have access to your home network resources (eg. printer). So giving money to some company that provides you with what you can set up for yourself for a LOT cheaper and with MORE benefits is ridiculous.
And now some education on how VPN actually works: Your traffic is encrypted and sent to the VPN server. The server then decrypts the VPN traffic and sends it to where you want it to go. Not only does the VPN server then have your unencrypted data (if it wasn't otherwise protected in say with SSL/TLS in HTTPS), you also didn't gain any additional protection. Your data is still unencrypted from the VPN server up to the destination. The security that VPN does provide is the encryption if your line up to the VPN server is not trustworthy, such as when you are in a foreign network. In such case the VPN encrypted traffic can leave your computer and interception between your computer and the wifi access point or router is secure. Because the former case (traffic is still unencrypted on the internet) is not covered by VPN, there is no benefit to having a third party supply it. The other thing VPN does is it sends out the traffic in your name, so to the destination it appears as though your traffic originated from the VPN server location, allowing to spoof the location. This might be helpful, but there are free proxies. Also did you know that there is LITERALLY a list of FREE VPN SERVERS you can use? Of course I wouldn't trust them, but for location spoofing over HTTPS it's quite enough. Also there are proxies.

hey, just a tip for better results: The grinding and mixing of the educts before Calcination (putting them in the Oven the first time)is quite essential, since the reaction is diffusion driven. The ions of Y, Cu and Ba diffuse across grain boundaries. The smaller the grain is, the better your results will be. Typically the grinding and mixing alone takes about an hour and is repeated several times with multiple Calcination processes. ALSO: After sintering the pellet most likely has a tetragonal crystal-structure, which doesn't give you the needed properties for superconductivitiy. You have to place the pellets in the oven again at about 540 °C (witch oxygen) for 10h to obtain a better orthorhombic crystal structure, which gives you the superconductivity you want.

Theoretically, with a weak enough magnet, the Meissner effect should be able to overcome the flux pinning. Then it's in a pure superconducting/Higgs phase, whereas what you have is a mixed phase where the high temperature insulating state is recovered along the pinned flux lines. With a strong enough magnet, the insulating phase should be completely recovered (even at low temperatures) and the Meissner effect will stop. In fact this might be why your larger magnet could not be held in place as easily. Gravity is easily overcome but the ability to repel fields decreases as the field gets stronger.

Try to drop a magnet trough a thick aluminium foil tube...il will drop slow...the effect is that non feromagnetic metals with small resistance like copper or aluminium close to changing magnetic field. If you have a change in the magnetic field close to copper a current will be induced in the copper...that curent will create a theoretical equal opposing magnetic field...but because copper still has a resistance the opposing magnetic field will not be equal to the changing one. Because the superconductor has no resistance the forces are the same abd the magnet will float. But because the effrct happens in changing magnetic field the magnet has to move to create one. The maget is not floating is just slowly getting closer, very very very slowly

Re: Pelletization

Squishing dry powder in a press can form a decent pellet; however, adding a few drops of some sort of "binder" can often help keep things together when pressing.

Often a "binder" of glycerine (or some mix of that with some polyvinyl alcohol or acetone) can help keep pressed "green" pellets together (in-one-piece) pre-sintering. The "binder" (i.e. glycerine and/or alcohols) should burn off easily when exposed to the high-temp "sintering"/"annealing" environment and thus leave you with prettier pellets.

@NileRed You can use your YBCO-Pellets to create a simple, pulsed gravitoelectromagnetic (GEM) field generator. Something that can kick somebody into his a.. (to be taken litteraly). Theory of the gravitomagnetic London-moment is explained here: http://esamultimedia.esa.int/docs/gsp/Experimental_Detection.pdf
To do so, you need a traction SCR (Silicon Controlled Rectifier) from an old electrical locomotive (about 4…4.5 kV breakthrough voltage and 2…3 kA continous current; that results in 15…20 kA surge current). Switching time should not exceed 1 µs. No cooling is required (pulsed operation). Then, you have to build an induction free stacked plate capacitor from copper foil and PMMA dielectricum with a capacitance of C=150…500 nF at 4 kV. (C=Epsilon·A/d), while Epsilon is the product of the vacuum permittivity Epsilon0=8.854 As/Vm and the relative permittivity of PMMA Epsilon-r=3). Further, you need some 1/2" copper tubing (skin effect) to contact your YCBO-pellet flat (!) by its faces in a narrow U-shape. Put the SCR in series with the capacitor. The positive pole should point upward. For low impedance without reflections, both tube conductors should be as short as possible and maintain a distance of about 30…35mm in between. Then submerge the contacted YBCO-Assembly into a Dewar-flask, fill it with LN and put a stripe from a non metallic substance (e.g. wood, polymer, glass, etc.) on top of the flask. This is your test mass. Load the capacitor to 4kVDC from a high-voltage lab power supply, then fire the SCR by connecting a 9V-Battery (positive to Gate, negative to Cathode). The test mass should fly about 2…3m into the air. Caution: This experiment uses deadly voltages. Note: No, you can't build a flying machine with this setup, since density of Cooper-Pairs is too low. It encompasses a couple of nm. To build something, like depicted in USN UAP-videos, you need a topological insulator at RT (e.g. nanoparticles from Bi), driven by RF (Radio Frequency) superposed with high DC voltage for polarization. This is exactly the opposite of a superconductor.

Cool. I actually made a YBCO superconductor as my final high-school chemistry/physics project back in the early 90s (when they were still a pretty new discovery). It wasn't quite so complicated a process, though. I started with the oxide powders, and just spent a few hours after school grinding them together into a super-fine powder with some sort of solvent (ethanol?). Then dried it, compressed it into a pellet, and sintered it in a furnace (regular air, not oxygen). To be fair, though, it didn't come out great. I was able to measure zero resistance with a multimeter, but getting a magnet to float took several tries to get it balanced. Moving it around just made it leap off. Probably similar to the results you got with your first attempt at the large run.

The floating magnet and the magnet keeping its orientation in space is both caused by the same effect. the effect is Faraday's Law of Induction. The falling magnet induce a current in the superconductor due to the fact that the falling magnet causes a change in magnetic flux linkage. But the induced current produce a magnetic filed that wants to stop the magnet from falling so it repels the magnet. The moment the magnet starts to move up,down or slide to the sides (even by micrometers), it causes a change in magnetic flux linkage, which induce a current in the supper conductor, which produce a magnetic filed to prevent the change that was causing the current in the first place. Because the superconductor has almost no resistance to current, small changes in magnetic flux can instantly produce large currents, thus large fields to oppose the change. This is the same effect as dropping a thick piece of copper on a large magnet, just that in superconductors  the effect is amplified due to no losses by resistance

Great video, superconductors are awesome. Couple of thoughts as a Chem PhD student.
We did this in Inorg lab a couple years ago. There's a paper that could have saved you a lot of work: "Simplified Synthetic Experiment of YBaCuO Superconductor for First-Year Chemistry Laboratory" by J. She and R. Liu (J Chem Ed, 2008). It lays out the general procedure you used, with the exact numbers. The paper (and us) started with the pure oxides, which avoids the messy synthesis and allows exact stoichiometric ratios. You mix the three oxides, grind them with mortar and pestle, then press them into pellets with a press. Then bake in the oven. The paper says it can be done in air, but we used a slightly oxygen rich atmosphere. Then it's fun with LN2 and magnets. Half an hour of synthesis, bake overnight, and done. You actually got to almost the exact dimensions in the paper, but with a lot more effort. Still the process is often the most interesting part. Still, it seems that you could have saved yourself a lot of trouble by starting with the pure oxides (should be available from most chem companies) and following the already discovered procedure. A good literature search can save you a TON of lab work.

J Chem Ed is a great journal, a lot of cool chemistry things that people have figured out how to do outside a full research lab. Definitely recommend looking through it before you launch a big project.

I wish I had some concrete advice regarding the production of NdFeB magnets, but all I can think of is that you will probably need a Nd-rich composition to facilitate sintering. The Nd-rich grain boundary phase also increases coercivity by creating some distance between the ferromagnetic grains and makes domain reversal harder. Industrially, rare earth magnets are treated some way or another to decrease grain size, else the magnetic properties are poop. For NdFeB, that would be HDDR or just HD for some others. That tube furnace will surely come in handy, I think 95% Ar + 5% H2 can be used for hydrogenation too (probably safer to handle).

Hi Nigel, the reason the YBCO ratios don't match the 123 is because in solid state reactions not everything reacts, and some gets burnt off. Also the best YBCO superconductors are slightly oxygen deficient. There has likely been quite a lot of synthetic optimisation to make the best superconducting pellet but has resulted in a seemingly nonsensical method. If you did some reitveld refinements off the final powder you would find the 123 ratio is preserved, and the oxygen is probably deficient

How have you never made your own magnet? Weak magnets are super easy to make if you aren't trying to over complicate it... Ah, I see now.

This procedure is simpler: (mix powders and bake it to YBa2Cu3O7)
First of all the starting substances, Y2O3, BaCO3 and CuO are weighed in (stoichiometric)... The weighed educts are now placed in a mortar and pestle for around 10 minutes until they are a homogeneous powder (...until it is uniform grey). Good mixing of the reactants is essential ... the powder is placed in a corundum (Al2O3) boat. subsequent this boat is placed in a furnace and heated to 950◦C. The powder will stay for 12h at this temperature. This procedure is called sintering. After the (...) sample is cooled to roomtemperature, the powder is mortared again into a fine powder. ...these powder, which is already YBa2Cu3O7... is pressed into pellets and sintered again 12h at 950◦C. This second procedure will be in a pure oxygen atmosphere...
Done
for more information: https://ph2.uni-koeln.de/fileadmin/Lehre/PraktikumM/M25-HTS-Tutorial_en.pdf

99,99% purity of yttrium oxide is way more than needed to make good YBCO. I used only 99,9% and it worked fine. I personally prefer "shake and bake" method for making YBCO. I just mix stoichiometric amounts of yttrium oxide, copper oxide and barium carbonate and grind it in a mortar. I use 20-30ml of oxygen per minute- just rough estimation from pressure drop in cylinder. The final sintering and annealing is made at higher temperature tha you mentioned- around 970-980C. You can also check my comment on Ben's video you mentioned, there's more details. You can make erbium barium copper oxide, which is highly paramagnetic at room temperature, which is cool. There you can see what i mean: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4FZ3eFYO6yE. BSSCO is a mess. I tried to make it once and it's much more complicated. I destroyed my alumina crucible and wasted chemicals. Bismuth oxide is highly volataile at high temperature and I suppose there is needed some kind of sealed container to process it.

In experimental physics research, it is very common to temper a little bit the exact details of the procedure, so that you can be ahead in the field, thanks to your (otherwise positive) results. The principle is that you get a very positive result, and you publish a slightly altered protocol, so that anyone willing to reproduce it will get it slightly off, and will have to take some time refining your process to get as good of a result as yours; during this time, you can continue advancing on your stuff while being ahead...
This is very bad practice but is, unfortunately, very common in experimental science :(

NdFeB magnets are made from powdered metals, aren't they? SmCo too for that matter. Possibly by casting as well, but maybe the stress of freezing is a lot to ask of these brittle intermetallic compounds? That'll be quite a challenge, working with reactive metal powders or alloys, in any case! That fused quartz tube will certainly be helpful. Won't be easy to work inside it, but at least it can be filled with inert gas, or even vacuum.

A good stepping stone project would be ferrites -- strontium and barium ferrites being hard (permanent) magnets, and MnZn and NiZn ferrites being soft magnets useful in high frequency circuits (in fact you saw some inside the furnace controller, the black squares with "680" on them are 68 microhenry inductors, enameled copper wire wound on a two-piece ferrite core, glued together). Indeed, most ferrites are magnets of some sort or another; magnetite itself is ferrous ferrite (FeO.Fe2O3).

You'll need an electromagnet strong enough to magnetize the products anyway, and that would be another good project. I don't think pulsed power is necessary for ferrites (so, some steel pole pieces, a beefy copper coil, and a car battery or rectifier, should do), but it may be desirable for the stronger ones. 1.5 tesla is a lot of flux density, and pole pieces won't help you very much as all other materials saturate at the same level!

Bonus: if you do make a pulsed magnet, you can launch aluminum discs with it. :)

A couple pointers for solid-state synthesis:

1. I would recommend putting the powder in an alumina crucible when you anneal it. As you noticed, spreading it out increases the surface area and makes the reaction with the gas faster. It also saves you from having to clean the whole tube every time, and protects it in case you try to make something that will eat your very expensive quartz tube (which could be some unexpected things at the temperatures you're dealing with).
2. You can grind the powder much finer with an agate mortar. If you want to go nuts you could even get a ball mill, which I would recommend if you intend to do more powder syntheses. You already bought the press, the die set, and the tube furnace, so why not complete the set?

Edit: I should clarify that by "crucible" I mean a large rectangular boat, not one of the teacup-shaped ones.

great video nile! couple of suggestions:
1. your tube furnace will be the temp you set only in the middle. there will be temp falloff the further you are from the heating elements (thing inverse parabola). take a long thermocouple and characterize this temp delta so you know how much space you can reasonably work with.
2. if you can find someone to melt together the end of a test tube and then cut it in half- you’ll have a nice tube furnace style crucible you can use to put your samples in to anneal :) this keeps your furnace tube clean for longer

19:55 "... instead of the standard Chinese one"
Me, an Australia: It just works!

We have the same plug design and standard of 230V vs China's 220V. Main difference is our plugs have little rubber guards at the base of the Live/Neutral pins and the pins themselves are a teeny bit thicker. Also often have longer ground pins. The idea for this is ground is always first to connect and last to disconnect, and when the plug is ~20% out of the outlet, the exposed part of the pins is insulated and you can't touch it.

Great video man, I've been building a YBCO cooking setup at home too these past 6 months and it was fun too see how our journeys were similar. I gotta get myself a magic bullet blender, that thing looks great for breaking up the sintered discs. Did you notice any long term wear on your mortar and pestle? I noticed you have a nice metal pestle. I do the solid state reaction but I find the oxide powders and the calcined powders leave a hard to remove residue on my ceramic mortar and pestle.

Remember that significatly less oxygen can penetrate your discs at high density, so if you are ever curious to try and maximize oxygen content just fully oxygenate the calcined powder then perform a cold sinter on the powder to achieve a disc at the required density without losing YBCO plane alignment and oxygen content from the high temperatures of traditional sintering. To do this you will likely have to modify your press to withstand 200 degree celsius temperatures while under the 8 ton load.

My dad was a founding member of the first commercial superconducting company, and then went on to work for the government running a group that focuses on height temp superconductors and the tech they make possible. As a kid I played around in his lab all the time. I even did a science fair project that used superconductors to measure the efficiency of different types of insulation at low temperatures.  As a kid, I had some serious health issues that necessitated frequent MRIs, and it always helped me to be less afraid knowing my dad worked on the tech that made them possible. We used to make production quantities of YBCO.  The raw metal oxides were measured and mixed in a steel ball mill (or maybe it was tungsten carbide balls?).  The mixture was put into a silver 'boat' for the tube furnace treatment.  What came out was caked, and it was broken up and put into the ball mill again.  This cycle was repeated about 3-4 times before being grown into a single crystal about the size of a hockey puck.  Those samples were really cool to play with because they would float a 1 inch cube NdFeB magnet about 3/4 inch above the surface.  You could really feel the magnetic forces.  You could press the magnet field further into the superconductor and then lift the magnet and superconductor out of the LN2 bath, with the superconductor spinning under the magnet.  I really wish I had kept those samples.  Those YBCO hockey pucks were being used as holding fixtures for steel aerospace assemblies.  They would be cooled down inside a dewar container and pulse-magnetized with a large capacitor bank and coil.  They would hold an extraordinarily strong field-many time larger than a NdFeb magnet which would hold the steel part in place against the magnet enclosure.  As long as they kept it cold it would hold the part strongly in place.  Releasing the part was easy, they just turned off the LN2 and the puck would go normal as it warmed up.

Copper oxide superconductors have CuO3 in mixed oxidation state between +2 and +3. The stoiciometry of the Cations, Yttrium and Barium is to stabilize this mixed oxidation state of Copper. The synthesis I saw at U C Santa Barbara was mixed oxides in a crucible in a microvave oven, absorbs microwave energy until fuses, oxidizes, becomes non-conductive as endpoint. Larger cations stabilize the CuO3 groups: Bismuth, Lanthanum for +3 Y and Sr, Pb, Hg for +2.  LaSr2Cu3O7 gives +2.3 for Cu.

You need Bi and Cu oxide, Ca and Sr carbonate, ball mill them for a day. Same two step bake process, I'm fuzzy on the temperatures, look it up. Some of the bismuth can be substituted with lead, like Bi 1.7 and Pb 0.3. IIRC that makes it fuse together better. The citrate process should also work but I have not done it that way.

Another note: there are two types of superconductors:
the ones that work at low temperatures (Hg for example), which we actually understand;
the ones that work at high temperatures (like YBCO), which we do not really understand.

The former are called Type I superconductors, while the latter are called Type II superconductors.
Flux pinning only happens in Type II superconductors,
so if you would have gone with Hg, that would not even have worked for the "anti-gravity" thing.

The oxide powders should also be ground very fine, as the sintering process is a solid state reaction where particle mobility isn't that high as long as nothing melts. At the university we had an agate ball vibration mill for this, usually overnight as it's noisy. Such fine grinding can't be done with a piston and mortar. And you have to use stuff that doesn't impurify your powder. Be also careful on what material you put your pellets onto for the sinter process. You'll be surprised how easily something inside the oven can ruin your solid state chemistry if chosen wrong.
YBCO is a bit forgiving if you don't get the composition on spot. It'll still be likely OK to give a working superconductor that works at temps of LN. But in the early days when YBCO hit the science community there was a big rush to find superconductors that would work at even higher temps. Trying to do the successful research therein, it was crucial to have precise control over a lot of variables: not only stoichiometry, but lattice defekt control, sinter temperature profiles and gas composition control, time of sintering, ... You open a big box of worms.
I wonder what make you think that if you dissolve your Yttrium oxide in nitric acid and impurities do that likely, too, how that should purify your Yttriumnitrate. Depending what the impurities are, they might precipitate together with the main nitrate. Nothing won then... But OK, won't nitpick with such chemical details as for your purpose it doesn't ruin the fun.

If you want to retry: mill as fine as you can, press into pellets, do the sinter process from the beginning with the pellets. You don't need much oxygen flow, a bubble trap at the outlet is nice for control. Longer sinter times could be beneficial but I forgot what we used in the solid state chemistry lab. Sometimes the temperature profile program is the "secret sauce"...

This looks to me like a Sol-Gel type synthesis. I did some of these for a research project with a group of ours that does a lot of work on solid-state reactions (made some Gadolinium-Iron Garnets and derivates thereof), so I have a bit of experience that is a little bit more detailed than some of what you've shown in the video.

As you mention, Cu(NH3) complexes are responsible for the very nice blue color that you see at first, but as you neutralise, what starts happening is that Citrate acts as a complexing agent. All the metal Ions in solution (this is why for these syntheses, you need to use easily soluble salts like nitrates and not the oxides) will then be nestled in a web-like structure connected by citrate ligands. The pyrolysis reaction you got was quite cool. Depending on the reagents used this can also be simply a relative un-spectacular step of drying the mixture: First into a gel, then into a powder. In my case I used Ethandiol as a complexing agent with nitrate salts and so the only think that happened is that at some point I produced some brown NOx gasses. These gels are also quite cool, as they can be used to make crystal-fibers or sponge-like structures that are mostly air (aerogels).

This technique has a significant advantage. To make YBCO, you could simple mix all the respective metal oxides in the appropriate ratio and then heat those at very high temperatures and thus obtain it in a solid state reaction. It is likely that you'd have to heat and then crush and re-mix it a lot of times but it would work in the end. By first making a gel and then drying that, you achive very even distribution of all the reactands (you are correct to say that after the pyrolysis reaction, what you have is mostly just this very fine distribution of all the oxides and/or nitrates). Because additionally the indivudual particles are much smaller, this brings down significantly (by something on the order of 100-300°C) the temperature at which you can do the solid state reaction, because the diffusion process has to cover much shorter distances and there is a lot more interparticle contact surface.

With these Sol-Gel Syntheses, it is common to do two heating steps (sometimes just one) to achieve a very fine result. It's not at all surprising that the very last superconductors, that you heated again for much longer, turned out way better. Very generally, you want to do a reaction first at relatively high temperatures for a relatively short amount of time, crush the obtained product into a fine powder, and do a second step at relatively low temperatures for relatively long. For this second step I believe I was keeping these garnets at 700-800 °C for like 18-24 h, but it all depends on what specifically you're making.

As a final note, if your final product is an oxide, it may be much more advantageous to do these reactions just on open air, if your oven and your lab can accommodate this. The oxygen content in the air that will naturally leak into systems like this is more than enough to saturate very slow solid state reactions like these, in my experience.

Cheers.

Around 29:50, commenting about how the magnet "recrystallizes"...
The crystals of the magnet at no point during the sintering process ever melt or de-crystallize. They simply diffuse through the crystal at a high rate, changing the properties. You never reach melt T for your powders, I guarantee that. You are simply encouraging diffusion to help the powders fuse together at their boundaries and decrease porosity%.

One of our Master's student lab exercises was to make YBCO pellets (by finely grinding the ingredients in a pestle & mortar, pressing them into pellets and baking them in crucibles using a program that went up to ~1000 °C), and then a lab assistant would demonstrate their superconducting properties with N2 (l) and tiny magnets. It was probably chosen because our teacher spent over a decade studying superconductors with her superior (our top professor and head of research group. I'm actually starting PhD studies under said professor now, though superconductors are no longer our focus.)

I've a few tips for improvement for you:

1. The ideal heating curve should include 12 hours for sintering at 950 degrees celsius and around 6 hours at 400 degrees celsius for tempering. Between these phases the oven should cool down at a rate of 100 degrees per hour. This process should be repeated a couple times including re-grinding the material into a fine powder after each run.
2. You only have to add the oxygen at the tempering phase: During the sintering phase a modification of YBCO is formed which hasn't superconducting properties. The superconducting modification starts to form at temperature below circa 500 degrees (between 500 and around 300). During this phase oxygen is embedded into the crystal structure while carbon escapes (if you use Barium carbonate of course carbon is present). I think at the tempering phase it goes from a tetragonal to an orthorhombic crystal structure. So you only need the oxygen during the tempering phase. That also means that increasing the time the pellet stays at 950 C doesn't increase oxygenation. The "quality" of your superconductors only increased because you did the process multiple times. (EDIT: To form a general YBCO crystal structure in the first place you have to sinter it at 950C first before tempering/annealing)
3. You can speed up the whole process by starting (buying) with Yttrium oxide, Barium carbonate and Copper oxide directly (EDIT: with "starting directly" I mean the step of heat treating the material/powder mixture inside an oven). You just have to grind them into a really fine powder (for example inside of a ball mill) to make it work. That's also the reason why Applied Science failed this "direct" method, because he didn't ground his powder mixture.
